comments.text:
+divebomber50 Let's look at it this way, I live about 1100 miles away from 
my home town and subsequently most of my family.  An average gasoline 
powered car with only one driver can realistically make the trip in 24 
hours including stops and a couple naps.  A Tesla Model S has 2 available 
battery options, but lets say for the sake of argument that it is equipped 
with the top of the line 85-kWh battery.  Now according to Tesla this 
battery offers a 300 mile range (now car and driver got an average range of 
just over 200 miles but I'll ignore that for the sake of argument), 
meaning, that you will have to stop and charge a minimum of 3 times along 
the way (more realistically 5 but......).  Not all charging stations are 
created equal, (according to Tesla) your standard house socket would take a 
whopping 60 hours to fully charge an empty 85-kWh battery.  But, say you 
luck out and find HPWC charging stations along the way (the fastest way to 
charge a Tesla outside of their own 75 minute super charge stations).  This 
will still take about 5 hours, meaning that on top of the minimum 18 hours 
of driving there is a minimum of 15 hours of charging.   So, in the 
absolutely most ideal scenario, a 24 hour trip takes you 33 hours.  Now, 
lets look at the FCX Clarity and give it the same best scenario possible 
like we did for the Tesla (IE: a scenario where proper refueling stations 
are available).  It only has a range of 240 miles.......but refueling takes 
minutes, not hours.

top_comment.text:
This isn't particularly true. Let's take Tesla's case. They are saying its 
bad to give the dealers in a state the right to sell the car. Really? Do 
you want only the manufacturer to sell directly? Where is the competition 
then? If a car is hot, it can jack up the price, just like Apple does by 
controlling the retail prices of its products. This is why Apple's products 
are basically the same price, whether you buy from Amazon or Best Buy, and 
if Best Buy offered a discount not allowed by Apple, it'd lose Apple 
products to sell. 

To allow competition - Which is what Republicans favor - the prices have to 
be different in one state from another with different local dealers 
competing against each other and we the consumer getting the best deal that 
we can negotiate. So the Republican argument actually favors competition, 
which the hosts conveniently don't talk about. 

Interestingly, I think Tesla itself will change its position one day when 
it starts to make more cars than the demand. When it will have excess 
inventory sitting in different states, it will have to allow local dealers 
to have the freedom to make deals and negotiate the prices. It will all be 
about basic economics of supply and demand. Again, the hosts don't get into 
that theory either. It seems it is easy for them to make the argument on 
politics than on economics, though they still make some good points that I 
did not think about.

What are your views? Hope my analysis makes sense :D﻿

comments.text:
If there were only brand of 1 car, made by 1 manufacture, then a monopoly 
on cars without a fair market and competitive pricing practices, would 
indeed cause prices to be inflated. In this case, we are only talking about 
one of hundreds of offerings in an extremely price sensitive automotive 
market. The competition to Tesla would come from any other model consumers 
compare it to, not from the other Tesla dealers down the street. Keeping a 
third-party franchised dealer out of the picture should lower the upfront 
transactional cost. Where the dealer network adds tremendous value (in my 
opinion) is their existing infrastructure for parts and service, including 
warranty repairs and maintenance, as well as many other areas that are 
often overlooked. In fact most automotive manufacturers arent even 
interested in selling direct to consumers because its been proven they 
arent any good at it (comparatively speaking). My only thoughts are, this 
is a very slippery slope and one that should be avoided. Free markets are 
like free speech or any other freedom thats best left that way. Once you 
start picking and choosing the laws based on someones ability to pay for 
them...oh wait...Im way too late for that one...anyway, if Tesla wants to 
sell a car directly to someone, unless there is something else im missing 
here, I see no legitimate reason for having laws against it.

comments.text:
+cobaltblue1975 While it is true that in the "traditional" sense of the 
word hydrogen is not "burned", it is still a reaction with oxygen.  That is 
essentially what burning means; rapid oxidation via application of intense 
heat.  In other words, when you burn something you are forcing the material 
to combine with oxygen.  The difference between "burning" a fuel and 
running it through a fuel cell is that the fuel cell does not require 
external heat be applied to it.

The "explosive nature" has nothing to do with an impact or breach.  All 
that is needed for the tank to explode is for the pure oxygen to be 
introduced to the hydrogen in a rapid manner.  Yes that is how you get 
water, but it also causes the tank itself to become highly flammable.  The 
Hindenburg comes to mind.

You do realize that "nuclear" is a fairly nebulous term, right?  Do you 
mean a fusion reactor or a fission reactor?  Because fission is actually a 
VERY well-established and stable power source.  Fusion is also very well 
established.  It is currently called solar, but it is still indirect fusion 
energy.

vehicle. The Hydrogen itself is not being burned like it would be in a

comments.text:
+moonyprongusa
1) You said: "I'm not the only one who believes in H fuel as the future"
Responses:
a) So what? Plenty of people believe stupid things. What does that prove? 
All you're proving is that there are other people just as uninformed as you 
are.
b) You don't know enough to comment or make claims. Your short attention 
span doesn't even allow you to learn enough to comment or make claims. Yet, 
you comment and make claims anyway.
c) Auto makers and energy policy makers cannot bank everything on any one 
technology, and I wouldn't do so either if I was in their shoes. That being 
said, you can tell which technologies are the leaders, vs. which ones are 
the "backup plans" purely by the amount of money they're spending on it. 
The department of energy has spent an average of $150 million per year on 
hydrogen fuel cell development/advancement in the past 10 years. They spend 
about $8 billion per year on battery electric car development. And, about 
the same ratio is true in all of the major auto manufacturers. Each major 
auto manufacturer is spending billions on battery electric car development, 
and only millions on hydrogen fuel cell development. These are the people 
who know this material 100x better than you and I put together, and their 
money is going into battery electric cars... globally... across the 
board... with few or zero exceptions. It's pretty clear to me that the best 
experts in the world think you're wrong, and if you don't believe it, 
follow the money.

2) You said: "Surely if RENEWABLE energy was used to power the electrolysis 
processes"
Response: Again - so what? You can grind up a tree to make a 
single toothpick if you want to. But, you can't make the argument that it's 
a smart use of the tree. It costs about $18K worth of solar panels to 
generate the amount of electricity needed to recharge the battery for an 
electric car every day. To do the same job with hydrogen fuel cells, it 
costs about $55K worth of solar panels to generate daily hydrogen to drive 
the same number of miles in a fuel cell car. Or, you can pay $55K and 
charge 4 battery powered cars. Just because an energy source is called 
"renewable" doesn't make it responsible or smart on any level to advocate a 
solution that wastes that energy that could be going into other things. Run 
your toaster. Heat your home. Whatever. The point is, "renewable" energy 
still isn't cheap energy, and still requires scarce resources. Wind 
turbines, solar panels, tidal energy generators, etc., are all very 
expensive, and all require maintenance, and you can't advocate 
INefficiencies simply because you've chosen hydrogen as your pet favorite 
(while being completely ignorant of the topics). If the hydrogen fuel cell 
car is going to be more viable than battery electric cars, it's certainly 
not going to be because of the use of renewable energy. No matter what way 
you spin it, you can't justify the energy waste on its merits alone, so 
don't even try. If hydrogen fuel cell cars win the race to market 
viability against battery electric cars (which is a 100-to-1 long shot at 
best, but who knows), it'll be because battery technology ends up costing 
too much, or they hit a standstill in development, or something like that. 
It will NOT be because you can justify the extra energy consumption, 
"renewable" or not.

3) You said: "thanks for the cookie"
Response: Go get a REAL education while you're eating your cookie. And, no, 
I didn't put your favorite drug of choice into the cookie, so don't get 
your hopes up.
comments.author: rockethead7

comments.text:
+rockethead7 Lemmie address three things:

2) Surely if RENEWABLE energy was used to power the electrolysis processes,

comments.author: moonyprongusa

comments.text:
+moonyprongusa
YOU SAID: "My position on H fuel is still the same."

- So, basically, you're incapable of learning.

YOU SAID: "You've brought up some interesting points about energy 
efficiency"

- Yeah, so my point about the massive difficulty and massive expense in 
making super-hardened engines capable of withstanding the beating of the 
violent and hot hydrogen explosions in combustion... that point meant 
nothing to you? Do you WANT cars with engines that cost $50K?

YOU SAID: "in that case, perhaps natural gas will become the fuel of the 
future, though there are potential adverse effects due to the fact that 
it's still a fossil fuel."

- Finally, you said something correct. Have a cookie.


YOU SAID: "Still not sold on electric cars."

- I wasn't trying to sell you anything regarding electric cars. I wasn't 
trying to sell you an electric car. I wasn't trying to sell you the concept 
of electric cars. I was commenting on your massive ignorance of the issues 
at hand, while you simultaneously professed knowledge you didn't have, and 
went around trying to "educate" others (with your silly and incorrect 
notions).

- Electric cars aren't ready to take over the gas market either. The best 
batteries available are lithium ion based, and that has many shortcomings. 
It is very expensive, and lithium mining cannot keep up with demand. It 
doesn't perform well in cold weather. And, the more you use them, the less 
the lithium ion batteries can be charged the next time, requiring expensive 
replacements too frequently for most people's liking. They're trying to 
combat this effect by not allowing you to charge/discharge the battery to 
full capacity, but then that results in cars like the Chevy Volt, which 
they've restricted to only about a 40 mile range on battery in order to 
preserve the battery's long term life. But, in today's world of technology 
advancements, I say confidently that battery/electric cars are far closer 
to "full" viability than hydrogen fuel cell cars.  And, as you've 
acknowledged, energy efficiency is a handicapping factor for hydrogen fuel 
cells which cannot be overcome (because it pertains to the very 
chemical/physical nature of the electrolysis process itself). Electric cars 
today are available (obviously), but they are still too expensive, and have 
too many shortcomings, to consider them viable (yet) for a typical middle 
class buyer. As battery technology advances, and as electric drivetrain 
technology advances, it's probable that battery electric cars will become 
the most viable option to displace gasoline powered cars.

- I don't have a crystal ball, however, and I cannot guarantee that battery 
electric cars will overcome their shortcomings and become the most viable 
non-gasoline alternative. But, as I said before, battery electric cars are 
about 20 years closer to viability than hydrogen fuel cell cars, and have 
energy advantages.
comments.author: rockethead7

comments.text:
+wahr1 Carbon dioxide has no direct effect on ozone, unlike CFCs and HFCs. 
Higher levels of carbon dioxide, however, do have an indirect effect on the 
ozone layer in the stratosphere. What effect it has varies with which 
atmospheric layer it's in and on the latitude. In the lower stratosphere 
(closest to the surface and close to the equator also where a lot of 
commercial jets fly) increased CO2 is slowing the production of new ozone 
(which may account for an increase in ozone restoration after the 
grounding) , especially in the spring. But near the poles and in the upper 
stratosphere, CO2 is increasing the amount of ozone by preventing nitrogen 
oxide from breaking it down. According to a study published in the March 
2002 Journal of Geographical Research by a joint research team from the 
University of Maryland and NASA, overall, the increased amount of CO2 in 
the atmosphere is speeding up the recovery of the ozone layer -- including 
the hole at the South Pole.  So CO2 in no way directly depletes ozone.

should be made at a business level....not a fucking legal level. This makes 
unions look like fucking leeches and I absolutely hate it. Tesla has no 
obligation to subsidize your old, outdated and pathetic business model of 
selling cars.

Get fucked.
comments.author: RyanB0011

comments.text:
What is stopping Tesla to change its policy when they cannot handle 
"servicing" by themselves? BTW the only thing complex about an electrical 
car are the things which are common to ICE engine cars... suspension.... 
how often you go in for a repair to the suspension ? How these cars perform 
time will tell but disapproving something because of not understanding 
technology is quite a classical problem.... like you understand your ICE 
car in and out anyway?
comments.author: sunder chitturi

comments.text:
+Akiva Green
Tesla can "afford" to come to you because they have so very few cars on the 
road. What's going to happen when they have 50K, 500K on the 
road?.........they certainly won't be able to do that anymore. You'll have 
to go to them. As to long-term reliability, time will tell......considering 
the immense electrical complexity, failures will certainly be coming fast & 
furiously. My experiences with three computer-cars(Eng, Trans, Body) has 
more of its shares of breakdowns. No other product has such long term 
commitments as the Automobile.......can you find parts for your 32 YO 
Refrigerator, Sofa, Vacuum, Boat...et.al.??
  Elon has taken on quite the giant undertaking, not quite realizing the 
immensity of his endeavor, typical of the Mega-Rich with pie-in-the-sky 
ideas, lofty ambitions, few specifics.
comments.author: Ricardo Ellison

comments.text:
Just go and ask a Nissan dealer or a Chevy dealer about electric cars they 
sell... They are so ill-informed. Why would a company such as Tesla who has 
just one selling product which only runs on electricity trust these dealers 
who refuse to change?
comments.author: sunder chitturi

comments.text:
+Ricardo Ellison Actually if something happens to your car all you have to 
do is call Tesla, they will come to you or go to one of their service 
centers. Also they have service centers, A lot of them and more to come as 
well. What they are simply doing is not having dealerships but showrooms in 
correct terminology. Also, when it comes to electric cars they don't need 
much maintenance and rarely breakdown like ICE cars so there should be no 
problem with their current way of doing things. 

http://www.teslamotors.com/findus#/bounds/26.21186,-80.09597699999999,26.070365,-80.2039691,d?search=,,service
,

http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2012/12/what-happens-when-the-tesla-model-s-breaks-down/
comments.author: Akiva Green

comments.text:
+nambinhvu I was commenting on OP. But I do agree, if you want a car you 
can't afford. Some people might think " well I'll just borrow it" it's 
stupid. You'll be left with no car again when you return it, and your money 
down the drain. Plus, for me, it would be uncomfortable to drive knowing I 
can't put a single scratch or dent on it. You're driving something that's 
not yours, and you don't get this sense of ownership. I want to actually 
own my own car that I can put money into it or something. People who lease 
should just get a cheaper car wtf.
comments.author: Jose Martinez

comments.text:
+Jose Martinez Some people are too poor to buy cars, so they lease them, 
which I think is dumber, because you're paying to borrow, not to own.
comments.author: nambinhvu

comments.text: Well you only buy a car once a couple years..
comments.author: Jose Martinez

comments.text:
I don't usually buy more than one car per day, but I guess if you really 
like cars and have an enormous amount of money it could be a hassle to go 
from store to store to buy all the cars you wanted.
comments.author: Hedning1390

comments.text:
+sunder chitturi Yes, because then in order to have what you want so you 
can buy at a dealer, they have to carry multiples of the same color as well 
as other colors and all the different models, do you know how much waste of 
space that is, especially when not optimized for storage, just so you can 
have them ready?  Not only that, but then the cars are sitting out in the 
sun in a lot, so they get dirty, and uv wear, then they have to constantly 
wash them.  You don't need a car right on the spot...All they need is one 
of each model there, then deliver it to your house.

Instead they can just make them to order, then make a few extra in case 
someone in the near future wants one.

Have one of each just for test drives at dealers, but if you think that is 
what a dealer is, then why are they so afraid of Tesla's direct sales 
approach...it's the same thing, test drive, then buy.
comments.author: nambinhvu

comments.text:
Ah so you buy a Chevy, then immediately somehow go and buy a ford (at the 
same place) and then a Toyota....Now how about a Honda! and hey they are 
all sold by the same shop. Do you even consider or re-thought what you 
wanted to write?
comments.author: sunder chitturi

comments.text:
It's called, buying over the internet, you don't need a physical 
store...physical stores aren't needed anymore for the most part, and are a 
waste of space and resources.  Physical stores are only good for seeing how 
things work in person or how things fit/feel/taste.  So they can set up 
product stores for that personal experience, where product manufacturers 
contribute to keep those places open, then there's the need for faster than 
1 day shipping, so you buy in person, but most things aren't needed right 
away.
comments.author: nambinhvu

comments.text:
+Ricardo Ellison But they did ban Tesla from Texas BECAUSE they didn't want 
to let them have a factory outlet. At least that's what I understood from 
the video.
comments.author: T0baws

comments.text:
+1mbA4ever Restrict it? That IS kinda stupid.There are many forces at 
work...one of which is the Unions. I've always worked at non-union shops, 
perhaps is is these  States that have differing laws about Unions. I had a 
protracted conversation with my Shop manager one day about Unions where he 
worked in California.....at a Union shop. Extremely counter-productive 
entity. Perhaps that is the driving force behind this "resistance"?.
comments.author: Ricardo Ellison

comments.text:
But you can't be sure that it will be fail. So why would you restrict it - 
kinda dumb from a European PoV
comments.author: T0baws

comments.text:
+Tom . One f the points I was making assures Tesla can succeed is that 
two-model few-years of production model/scenario. This scenario doesn't 
exist in any other Automakers experience. As such, it is a fantasy within 
most every business venture.
 Tesla can do this....especially with the immense financial support 
available. Long term I believe will ultimately fail.
comments.author: Ricardo Ellison

top_comment.text:
The dealers don't make much on a sale, they do however make a killing on 
after sale parts and service
And the manufacturers make their money on after warranty parts sales
Tesla doesn't want any part of that model
Best bud worked at service dept eight years for a Mercedes dealer, so take 
the info for what it's worth to you﻿

comments.text:
+CheekyMonkey888  And since Tesla has fewer moving parts, it needs even 
less maintenance! It says a lot when no consumer is defending the 
"stealerships" because they provide a shitty service and Tesla's customer 
service rocks!
